item.title: rOpenSci Slack emojis
item.description: HAPPY world emoji day! üåè üêî üìÜ In honor of this momentous occasion, I have decided to analyze the emojis used on rOpenSci‚Äôs Slack. library("dplyr") ‚äïIf you‚Äôd like to follow along, go fetch yourself a Slack token. token <- "MY_SLACK_API_TOKEN" ## stick your token here We will first use Slack‚Äôs reactions.list method. ‚äïNotice here I am pulling the items from the response and then from each item I am interested in the message reactions.

item.title: runconf17, an analysis of emoji use
item.description: I had such a delightful time at rOpenSci‚Äôs unconference last week. ‚äï21 üì¶ were produced! Not only was it extremely productive, but in between the crazy productivity was some epic community building. Stefanie kicked the conference off with ice breakers, where we explored topics ranging from #rcatladies & #rdogfellas ‚äïfor the record, I‚Äôm an #rchickenlady, IT‚ÄôS HAPPENING to impostor syndrome. It was an excellent way to get conversations starting! work Karthik and I worked on two packages:

item.title: ENAR in words
item.description: I had an absolutely delightful time at ENAR this year. Lots of talk about the intersection between data science & statistics, diversity, and exceptional advancements in statistical methods. "By a small sample we may judge of the whole piece" -- -- I loved it, but let‚Äôs see what others were saying! Check out this word cloud of the most commonly tweeted words. This certainly sums up my experience.

item.title: Yoga for modeling
item.description: A New Year‚Äôs resolution for all of our models: get more flexible! As an aside, I‚Äôm better at implementing yoga for my models than yoga for myself, most of the time I end up like this: Anyways, let‚Äôs make our models flexible! By flexible, we mean let‚Äôs be more intentional about fitting nonlinear parametric models. What do you mean by nonlinear modeling By nonlinear modeling, we mean fitting parametric models with nonlinear terms.
